sentences.sentence: Almost 20 years ago, Federal Court of Canada Judge Andrew MacKay delivered his decision on the legal status of Helmut Oberlander.

His findings were clear: Oberlander had been a member of a Nazi mobile killing unit (Ek10a) for a period of 18 months or more between 1941 and 1942; he had served as an interpreter in a unit whose role was to murder civilians; and he had misrepresented or failed to disclose his wartime activities when he arrived in Canada and later received Canadian citizenship.In his ruling, MacKay argued that had Oberlander been truthful, he never would have been admitted to Canada and would not have been granted citizenship.Following this decision, Oberlander's supporters and his legal counsel claimed, among other things, that the decision was unfair because it provided no opportunity for appeal.

Events of the past two decades give ample evidence that this was not the case.Indeed, in the intervening years, multiple attempts to remove Oberlander from Canada have been thwarted, as his lawyers have variously argued that their client's behaviour in Canada, the health of his family members and questions of duress should be taken into consideration.
Each successive challenge sent the file back to the government's lawyers for revision.

The last challenge was rejected by both the Federal Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court of Canada.Now, with all avenues seemingly closed, Oberlander's lawyers have unveiled a new legal argument.In essence, they claim that MacKay was entitled to make a finding only as to whether or not Oberlander misled authorities in order to gain entry into Canada and later receive citizenship.
Everything beyond that was merely opinion on the part of the judge and therefore is of no force or effect.
They further argue that even if their client was properly stripped of citizenship, he retains "domicile," and therefore cannot be deported.
"Domicile" is an old Roman legal concept that predates government involvement in immigration.
It refers to a fixed place of residence.
It meant (more or less) one's primary place of residence, or the place with which that person has the strongest factual connection, and could refer to a country or territory.
There is a lot of obscure law connected with domicile.

Today in Canada, however, it is all irrelevant, since the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act has repealed the applicability of the concept, both going forward and looking backward.Helmut Oberlander is seen in an undated photo.Citizenship law is a very modern concept governed by legislation and connected to an international body of linked laws and treaties, and it is all that counts.A sensible view of the matter was expressed by Mark Freiman, former deputy attorney general of Ontario and former legal counsel and president of the Canadian Jewish Congress, who observed that this latest legal salvo cannot obscure the important truth that Oberlander is being deported not only because he lied when filling out his immigration form, but because he was found to have been complicit in crimes against humanity.
He is subject to removal from Canada on that basis alone.So how was Oberlander complicit?

The Federal Court agreed with government counsel that "Oberlander was involved with Ek10a while 'knowing' what Ek10a did," and that "given the length of time he was with the unit he could not have been unaware.

"The Federal Court "considered the vital role played by interpreters in the Ek10a, and (that) there was expert evidence in the record that interpreters (for Nazi mobile killing units) 'were often witnesses to maltreatment; they were present at executions; here, they conveyed orders to the victims before the executions (remove clothes, hand over valuables).'

"In the words of Judge James Russell, who delivered the 2015 Federal Court decision in Oberlander v. Canada: "Complicity is found for individuals who 'intentionally or knowingly contribut(e) to a group's crime or criminal purpose."
Russell added that, "There is evidence... to suggest that (Oberlander) played a role as an interpreter in interrogations that could have resulted in the death of the person interrogated.
"Oberlander was part of a murder machine that slaughtered thousands of innocent Jews.
He was complicit in the actions of his unit.
He lied in order to gain entry to Canada and obtain citizenship.

No amount of legal hair-splitting by Oberlander's lawyers will change that finding.He should be deported without further delay.Bernie M. Farber and Len Rudner were executives with the Canadian Jewish Congress, who, along with others, had carriage of the Helmut Oberlander case for over 25 years.Ex-Nazi Helmut Oberlander is too frail and mentally diminished to deport from Canada, his lawyers say(https://nationalpost.com/news/helmut-oberlander-is-too-frail-and-mentally-diminished-to-deport-over-wartime-nazi-past-his-lawyers-say)Second World War hero Pte.

Devries exemplified the very best of Jewish honour(https://nationalpost.com/news/second-world-war-hero-pte-devries-exemplified-the-very-best-of-jewish-honour)Police turn to an elaborate sting operation after the investigation into a woman's death goes cold.
Listen to Episode 3 of She's Gone: !

His findings were clear: Oberlander had been a member of a Nazi mobile killing unit (Ek10a) for a period of 18 months or more between 1941 and 1942; he had served as an interpreter in a unit whose role was to murder civilians; and he had misrepresented or failed to disclose his wartime activities when he arrived in Canada and later received Canadian citizenship.In his ruling, MacKay argued that had Oberlander been truthful, he never would have been admitted to Canada and would not have been granted citizenship.Following this decision, Oberlander's supporters and his legal counsel claimed, among other things, that the decision was unfair because it provided no opportunity for appeal. Events of the past two decades give ample evidence that this was not the case.Indeed, in the intervening years, multiple attempts to remove Oberlander from Canada have been thwarted, as his lawyers have variously argued that their client's behaviour in Canada, the health of his family members and questions of duress should be taken into consideration. Each successive challenge sent the file back to the government's lawyers for revision. The last challenge was rejected by both the Federal Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court of Canada.Now, with all avenues seemingly closed, Oberlander's lawyers have unveiled a new legal argument.In essence, they claim that MacKay was entitled to make a finding only as to whether or not Oberlander misled authorities in order to gain entry into Canada and later receive citizenship. Everything beyond that was merely opinion on the part of the judge and therefore is of no force or effect. They further argue that even if their client was properly stripped of citizenship, he retains "domicile," and therefore cannot be deported."Domicile" is an old Roman legal concept that predates government involvement in immigration. It refers to a fixed place of residence. It meant (more or less) one's primary place of residence, or the place with which that person has the strongest factual connection, and could refer to a country or territory. "In the words of Judge James Russell, who delivered the 2015 Federal Court decision in Oberlander v. Canada: "Complicity is found for individuals who 'intentionally or knowingly contribut(e) to a group's crime or criminal purpose." Russell added that, "There is evidence ... to suggest that (Oberlander) played a role as an interpreter in interrogations that could have resulted in the death of the person interrogated."Oberlander was part of a murder machine that slaughtered thousands of innocent Jews. No amount of legal hair-splitting by Oberlander's lawyers will change that finding.He should be deported without further delay.Bernie M.
